403b

Wages aren't competitive for my field because it's a hospital. Though my first career move, i hear it's better working for a design firm or something of the sort.

The staff I directly work with is most all old enough to be my mother. Out of 30 people in the department 3 are men.

Parkings a pain, to live anywhere close you have to live in the ghetto. Otherwise you'll be driving an hour to 30min driving time depending on time of year.

review_title: You can learn a lot working here, but don't expect to be compensated or treated as an equal
pros:
-Worthwhile mission
-Respected organization with a good reputation
-Many passionate employees who work towards improving patient care
-The majority of employees are hard working and intelligent; you can learn a lot from them
-Opportunities to work on many different projects
-Red tape is minimal and the organization's operations run smoothly
cons:
-You are expected to "do more with less"
-A lot of the leaders are arrogant and don't actually want to hear what their subordinates have to say
-Doctors walk on water and expect everyone to cater to their needs
-There is a lack of manners, and everyone thinks they are busier than everyone else; you will have to pick-up trash after meetings/events because people think they are above throwing their trash away
-You can "fully meet expectations" in your annual review and receive a 1% "merit-based" raise, which doesn't even cover cost of living
-Unless you change departments, there are minimal advancement opportunities
-They charge for parking and you will still have to walk across campus to get to your office
-Most benefits are being taken away and the cost of healthcare is rising

job_title: Health Unit Coordinator in Cleveland, OH
pros: Large company with many, many positions. Room for advancement. Tuition reimbursement. Life insurance is double your salary with the option to purchase more.  You can purchase life insurance for your spouse. Immediate health insurance coverage from day one of employment. Fmla.
cons: Low pay, under staffed, hit or miss with good management. High turn over, which I believe is due to short staff, heavy work load, possibly poor management. There is an employee handbook within which all the rules are listed however, the employee handbook also states that All rules are by managers discretion which can lead to partiality. One example of Managers Discretion: at the Cleveland Clinic 36 hrs is considered full time however there is a manager on a cardiac step down unit that allows 36 hrs to be full time for nursing staff only, not for PCNA (nurse aids/assistants) they must work 40 hrs to be full time. To my knowledge, no other manager does this. That falls under "Managers Discretion"  Point system is also many times not fair for everyone do to Managers discretion but this is how it should work, Points system: 18 pts for 40hrs 16 pts for 36hrs.  One call off is 3pts +1pt if you call off the second day in a row. -1pt if you punch in early and -1pt for punching out late. No sick days so pts add up fast which will put you in corrective action. When in corrective action you can not post for other positions.

pros: Great resources, great health insurance if needed, #2 hospital!  Patients complex especially at main,-great learning, tuition reimbursement, my coworkers and patients keep me here.  I love my job!
cons: Still among the lowest paid nurses.  Even with the latest increase. New nurses receive better raises than experienced and unit involved nurses, point system is not conducive to caregivers. I must come to work sick not to get an occurrence, staffing-they take floors that have tried to adequately staff and make them go up in patient load to accommodate units that haven’t staffed appropriately all the time!  Nurses really don’t have a say as much as they tout we do. Upper management  (includes doctors) make huge decisions affecting complete units without consulting the “worker bees” and have no idea the true ramifications of their decisions on the “working staff”.

review_title: Fairview IT Clinical Assistant for University of MN Physicians Heart
job_title: IT Clinical Assistant in Edina, MN
pros:
100% support from ALL Senior level IT employees.  I loved my team they are great!
Relaxed job most of the time
90% of the UMP employees are nice and respectful.
cons: Fairview IT supplied IT support for University MN Physicians Heart.  I worked on site for the two floors that UMP Heart rented out from the hospital.  While Fairview was great and supportive the environment at UMP had bad apples.  It was always the same doctors, nurses, admins complaining and starting drama for the sake of starting drama because they are divas.  DIVAS.  my goodness! One head admin asked for a two screen monitor set up and when she got what  she wanted she still complained because the monitors weren't 'matching monitors'.  One doctor would come by and just belittle me and tell me how to fix IT problems on his computer but he had NOOOOO clue what he was talking about! Another nurse demanded that she get a NEW computer on the spot and when I offered to let her use a laptop in the mean time she claimed she wasn't 'trained' to use a laptop. pros: You do learn a lot working alongside some very intelligent people at CCF. The benefits are some of the best out there, and many employees truly care about the patients' well-being.

Staffing is always short, and management does not seem to bat an eyelash.

The culture overall seems a bit feigned once on the floor, as you have to cut corners almost or run like a chicken without a head to accomplish the job requirements (beds, total baths, charting hourly for sometimes 24 patients, sometimes unmotivated staff). 
The points system for attendance is very strict, understandable, but sometimes harsh for sickness (probably abused because of burnout).

review_title: Cleveland Clinic is very doctor-focused, less nurse-focused
job_title: Patient Companion In the Float Pool in Cleveland, OH
pros:
-Working PRN allowed me to make my own work schedule and not work holidays
-Managers in the float pool were receptive and organized
cons: Being a nursing staff support person and a nursing student who is about to graduate, I can attest that many nurses at CCF are unhappy with their jobs. Most of the time, even if I had a difficult patient and required immediate assistance, nurses and other staff members were unwilling to enter the patient's room to assist me. I was told on several occasions by RNs, "This is your patient and you are responsible for managing this person's care." These statements were ridiculous, as I was simply a sitter and the RN was ultimately responsible for managing the care of the patient. In contrast to my experiences at University Hospitals of Cleveland, where nurses are always consulted when physicians are making major decisions, at CCF nurses took a backseat and were much more rarely consulted when patients' statuses changed. All of these factors contributed to a poor attitude exhibited by many RNs on multiple floors, which ultimately lead nursing support persons to become demoralized and frustrated.

Now the new grad can not get a job because this is on his nursing license.  don;t listen to employee complaints, required to work long hours if salaried (more than 40 per week) without compensation, if supervisor does not like you will try to get you fired. This is mt opinion from my own experience and from information from other employees that this has happened to.

review_title: It was the best of times, it was the worst of times.
pros: (1) decent health benefits, (2) access to some of the best health care in the US and abroad, (3) interesting work, (4) liberal PTO, (5) satisfaction in knowing you are able to help patients
cons: Because the Clinic is such a large organization, there are many divisions, and, of course, department directors, managers and supervisors.  It is up to the manager's discretion how to enforce certain rules and regulations regarding time management and other issues that can affect employee morale.  As a result, there can be dissention among the ranks.

job_title: Appointment Center Representative in Solon, OH
pros: Health Benefits, PTO when you can use them.
cons:
We had to answer the phones with "Can I schedule you an appointment for today?" when we darn well KNEW that we could not get them an appointment "today". This was never explained in any ad, billboard or letter to patients. We would get screamed at when we'd say "sorry, I don't have an appointment until 3 months from now". 

Coworkers would refuse to take calls, which would go back into rotation and go to the next agent. A handful of agents would be doing the work of a full call center. 

Non-stop calls all day long. Sometimes there would be 50-60 calls holding. Majority of people went home at 5pm; however, calls would flood in during that time.

Vacation request would never get approved or go into a "black hole". I was refused vacation time to extend my time away from work and the state to attend a FUNERAL. I had to bring this issue up to my boss's boss to get approval.

Was told that holidays would be rotated out, only to be told "well if your work day falls on a holiday, then you work it". 

Not aligned with the rest of CCF, it felt like I was working for a company that works FOR CCF.

review_title: My work experience was fair. I got out of it, what I put into it.
pros:
Patients-  population are mostly self insured, mostly educated and have adequate resources to assist themselves.
some benefits are good- healthcare is not that great. Its free to see the doctor at your own hospital (confidentiality is kind of skewed here) but you can go out of network for additional costs. The 403B is actually good, they match up to 2%.
cons:
Patients- well off people sure do know how to complain.
Compensation- on the lower side.  As a new graduate they offered me  an hourly salary that is 5 dollars less than the national average and the local average.  They also offered a friend of mine (with a degree looking for a higher up job) a salary that was 15,000 dollars less than market value. I took the job, but my friend didn't and ended up making more money elsewhere.

review_title: ABUSIVE ENVIRONMENT FOR NURSES, ESP. NEW NURSES!
pros: They have a strong reputation and they know it.
cons: If you are a nurse applying to the Cleveland Clinic, BEWARE! This is a doctor hospital and that's all they seem to care about! They make all their new nurse hires take an online assessment called PBDS. The test requires nurses to make a MEDICAL DIAGNOSIS! I am all about educating and empowering nurses, but this organization uses intimidation to deflate the confidence of its new nurse hires!! They will make you go through an Immersion Program and treat you like a kindergartener as they teach you their "dot method" for diagnosing patients' problems!! I have never been in a more demeaning and punitive environment!! THIS IS DEFINITELY NOT AN ORGANIZATION THAT TREATS IT'S NURSES WELL!! What a shame too, because as an experienced nurse I know the value of nursing care in patients' outcomes!!

pros: Benefits are decent-pay is well below average for such a large profitable company
cons: If you ever want to be paid your worth, you will quickly learn that you need to leave and come back, losing the position that you are happy in. And this, is no matter how much you are "engaged" in your department. There is never a bonus or material recognition given. You will never receive a pay raise based on your seniority or performance reviews. You can count on being held to a stagnant pay rate, with pathetic merit increases for your entire career, This makes it very challenging to be all in. Work/life balance is almost non existent as well as flexible schedules or remote options, although they say they have them, they do not really exist or are not readily offered.

pros: Helping patients and using your skills was rewarding. Some of the patients were nice and friendly.
cons:
Manager was a psychopath and a control freak. Played favorites with employees. Was working 12 hour shifts with no lunch break till the last hour, for like 10 minutes. You have to be at multiple places at once which is impossible. The nurse assistants (us) were severely understaffed. Was disrespected by other staff members and management, you're basically the bottom of the barrel and have take crap from everyone. Some of the patients treat you like their slaves, kick and punch you, abuse you etc. You basically wipe patients bottoms and do whatever they want because you are a slave even though most are capable of doing that themselves.
This job is not for sensitive people. They treat you like garbage and pay almost nothing. They have you running around while other nurses are on Facebook or wasting time. There were too many to list. I advise people to not bother with this job. Rather be working at a store.

review_title: Not very proud to work there, but it pays some of the bills.  I guess it's better than being unemployed.

pros: It's a steady income, i have affordable health care coverage and  i'm able to help people .
cons: An embarrassing low hourly wage, it's run like a corporation, not healthcare, many rules to follow so the company can  control/monitor employees lives outside of work. There is more money spent on image than on more important things .i.e. flat screen t.v's/marble floors, fancy fountains everywhere  vs.updated equipmt. to save paper / $, very low hourly wages, more parking for employees,(not a rock pit when they have to wear their 'required dress shoes/heels and pantyhoes' to work. Poor communication between the Dr's. office, patients and ROI.

review_title: Great to start in medicine, or if you are senior person
pros: Great name, works hard to improve their image and facilities, has many long-term people who stay there for entire careers, lots of training and development, great job opportunities once you are inside to change areas.
cons: It's Cleveland (what else can I say), although there are plenty of really nice areas in Ohio to live and do a little commute. As a very large health system, it has a heavy political element. And you can drink the Kool-aid and be a "team" player, or be part of the majority of people who are happy to have a job in the area. Lots of cross-town rivalry between Case Western and University Hospitals, but it also provides another opportunity to change jobs if you don't like one (join the other).

review_title: Limited career advancement opportunity and Management/HR misalignment with institutional motto.
pros: The Cleveland Clinic employs the most people in Northeast Ohio and is the second largest employer in the state of Ohio.  The compensation and benefits package are comprehensive and fair.  It is a world class facility with world class resources and a great place to gain experience and have on your resume.
cons: Being a vast institution does not necessarily lend itself well to employee career development and it can be easy to get lost in the shuffle at the Cleveland Clinic.  Also, managerial oversight can be lacking due to the size of the institution and great responsibility and workload placed on management.

pros: Very caring of their employees, great benefits and being in the top 5 hospitals of the country, they know what they need to succeed. Employees provide quality care and is like one big family.
cons: They would benefit from weeding out those who only work in healthcare for the pay from those who have a passion. They often come across as lazy and unempathetic.

job_title: Senior Patient Account Representative in Sacramento, CA
pros: I really enjoy working for the Cleveland Clinic. Health benefits and retirement benefits are great.
cons:
Micro-management.  Everything is based on management discretion.  They take advantage of this and use it to their benefit.  It’s not what’s best for the team, it’s what’s best for them.  You basically have to be a robot or they will make your life hell (unless you are a favorite). They somehow hire family and friends without experience. I have even found my supervisor sleeping at his/her desk on more than one occasion. Also, they are usually playing games on their phone when I come into their office.  

For fear of losing your job, you can’t go to higher management or HR.  They even skew the employee engagement surveys.  Management has called me out on my “anonymous” survey because they knew my writing style. Bottom line, management does what they want, no questions asked. 

I am only speaking for my department, I know there is awesome management within the Cleveland Clinic, just not in this department.

review_title: You couldn't pay me to go back there.
job_title: Certified Pharmacy Technician in New Franklin, Stark, OH
pros: The benefits start the day you are hired. Uniform is provided, generally comfortable, and given at least a 5 day supply. If you are hired before a certain part of the year you can get a small increase in pay with everyone else. Sometimes you'll get to meet interesting patients there.
cons: The managers are supposed to give feedback, but don't know their job very well to begin with. The co-workers gave my manager unfair and fake feedback about my performance in the job and the manager used that as my review, not by what the manager saw but based on word of others whom had a habit of talking trash. You have to pay for parking on property they already own. And with the benefits you can't go to any outside doctors or hospitals or it's not covered. They will hold it against you for any time taken off in the new hire period, but yet when they tell you not to come in because you are sick with a fever they will hold it against you later via a point system.

pros: Good people that I work with.  Approachable if I had any questions at all.  Having the oppurtunity to use top tier equipment.
cons: Redundant work.  Double and triple charting things b/c the management wants to implement new computer programs, on top of existing ones, that don't really affect patient care at all; it is essentially just carrying over to the second program the same information that exists in the first program.  Management cares very little about scheduling.  An example is: I worked the eve of the holiday on every holiday that I was supposed to have off, as well as holidays that I was scheduled to work. If i worked day shift this would not be an issue, but because I work nights i'm really working 7-8 hours on the holiday and coming home and sleeping.  Management knows, but they just don't care.  Thought it may have just been that first year of me working, but it continued into my 2nd year.

review_title: Some good, some bad - generally frustrating overall
pros: Pay is manageable, although, possibly below market rate.  Benefits are decent.  Some co-workers are friendly.  My supervisor is a good guy, fair, and reasonable (i.e. very un-Clinic-like).
cons: An abundance of politics and bureacracy is present in the work environment at all times.  To many levels of management, too many cooks always stirring the soup, too many people to report to and get approval from before proceeding with anything.  Plenty of preaching about one thing, and then doing the opposite.  Processes are inefficient in alot of areas.  In too many instances, "everyone" does their own thing and is not willing to "think like one health system" (hopefully, that is changing).  There are so many projects and initiatives going on at one time that nothing can get done in a reasonable amount of time without significant unpaid overtime.  I truly believe we do everything we can to give our patients the best care and overall experience.  However, I think non-medical employees are not treated very well, overall.

job_title: Senior Research Technologist in Cleveland, OH
pros:
Healthcare benefits are absolutely fantastic and 100% worth it.
Access to gym and other healthy choice options for free are a plus.
cons:
Overall: Not really one that pops up.
Position: Sort of stuck in the position. Hard to get promotions/raises that make you want to stay and keep working towards something. Sort of the same thing day-to-day promotion or not.

review_title: Surreal. Getting too big too fast.
job_title: Patient Service Representative in Independence, OH
pros: In the beginning benefits, but that changed quick.
cons: Horrible middle management. Very unprofessional and incompitant HR. Extremely understaffed. Work was too excessive with inadequate staffing. Dirty work tactics. No privacy, everyone in my department knew what was going on in my personal life because my manager had no sense of privacy towards employees. I learned when I was on medical leave that my employess would discuss my personal buisness in our staff meetings. If you work in an environment where confidentiality is stressed why can't you practice this with your employees. This was brought to the attention of HR only for the manager to be called to HR, then the manager come back to yell at me after the discussion with HR. Way to go HR, you were trained well. It's all buisness and politics with the clinic. The true workers get dumped on and the horrible ones get away with murder.

review_title: Great name; not an outstanding place to work.
job_title: Coordinator, Main Campus in Cleveland, OH
pros: The benefits are good; the Wellness Plan offers a free membership to the fitness center.
cons:
Employee benefits are good, but the boasted tuition reimbursement so much that it hardly makes a difference in cost (and then you owe the company time working here after achieving degree, whether or not you're able to find an opportunity to use your new degree).

Annual merit increases are unfortunately the complete minimum.

There is very little room for growth if you start at entry level.  I am over-qualified for my entry-level position and have always been turned down for new opportunities by people who are way overqualified. I have a degree and have only moved laterally from entry-level position to entry-level position.  It's a very frustrating professional setting.

The nepotism is insane. I'd heard this and didn't buy it until it happened to me in a major way.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Rocky River, OH
pros: Continual growth challenges and improves / develops current skill set. This can be included as a con as well. If you plan to work at the Clinic, I would suggest that you always keep your ear to the ground for new opportunities within the Clinic - even if lateral, this will keep things for you from getting stale.
cons: Continual growth leads to management always having new requests without discontinuing the current list of duties leading to an overwhelming feeling at times. Current cost savings initiatives have reduced the number of employees while new demands / projects continue to occur. Too much after hours work makes taking time off difficult especially when you will most likely be the only one that knows how to complete your tasks (lack of cross-training).

review_title: my experience with the Cleveland Clinic is mostly positive.
pros: Working for the Cleveland Clinic comes with representing a company that is world class and prestigious.  My favorite thing about working there is the opportunity to meet people from all over the world and hear stories about their lives.
cons: The worst part about working for the Cleveland Clinic is probably the location of the facility.  I don't always feel safe driving to work because of the high crime in the area. Plus, the roads in the area are really bad and they tear up your car.

review_title: As a whole....good company.  Individual, non-clinical departments.....no so much.
pros: Excellent benefits. Opportunity to advance.  Flex scheduling.  Many programs offered to help keep employees healthy.
cons: A lot of departments have a "not my job" mentality which makes it hard on everyone.  Or, they don't collaborate when implementing new processes that will negatively affect other departments.  It is difficult to be heard when making suggestions to fix these things.  The Clinic's technology is advancing faster than its employees can learn it.

pros: Great working environment and team members.  I am very autonomous in my role and can tailor my day how best I see fit.  I love working this way, makes me more effective and I feel more in control of my daily outcomes.  Great boss, very accomodating, approachable and personable.  Cares very much about my personal and professional growth.  CCF encourages employees to pursue higher education and tuition reimbursement is very generous.
cons: Too many task force meetings to make a decision on one small change.  My prior organization was smaller and changes were much quicker to implement.  This may not be something that would be easy to change, might just be a challenge of any large organization.  Inefficient systems that are outdated and slow on the administrative side.  Medically we are so advanced, but administrative side we suffer and waste much time this way.

pros: By far the best hospital in the world.
cons: Pushing out the more mature, knowledgeable, experienced, empathetic and reliable employees that help to give the Cleveland Clinic it's reputation.

review_title: Better be willing to do "more with less".
pros: Great benefits.  Great environment for wellness.  I gained industry expertise and had to opportunity to show my value to the organization.
cons: Since a cost cutting program started, the general feeling is that you better be willing to do 2x the amount of work and be grateful to just have a job.  I have been working 50-60 hours per week for the last 2 years.  Not much quality of life....I do get some minor pats on the back, but truly do not feel valued for my unwavering dedication.

review_title: A Great Organization That is Making a Difference
pros: A organization with a desire to improve the world.  Solid professionals at all levels.  Personal development and education are encouraged.  People who work here really care about each other, our patients and the company.  We are out to change the world!
cons: Corporate environment is increasing which means more of a big business mentality and all the associated negatives.  Increasing rules and regulations can improve how things run but there has to be a balance with personalizing the work environment.  CCF is literally a sterile environment which we all want for good patient care yet we want to keep nurturing this as a very warm place for employees and patients which we all want for both good employee care and good patient care.  So it's like all things balancing the good with the bad but this is a business so as employees we have to keep this in mind.

pros: Working for one of the largest health organizations in the nation with cutting edge technology and resources.
cons: Uncomfortable work environments. I was terminated from my employment after 90 days (still training) I was put on a plan to make changes in work performance. The changes were made successfully but with no labor union or employee protection it's to managements discretion what they so choose. I was basically terminated from my employment for being a new employee on the job. Why hire someone you weren't willing to train ? The clinic is too big of an organization for their own good. So big they overlook those who matter most, their employees. The best employees are the best caregivers unfortunately politics and who they "like" takes precedent

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Wheat Ridge, CO
pros: The staff here is very competent and there is a stated culture of being kind and considerate to both patients as well as to one another.  Great goal and of course some people are more successful at this than others.  Can't control that.  People who do a job well have options to move up or laterally depending on their credentials. There are many people here who have been here for well over 10 years - overall I like working here.
cons: Healthcare industry is under tremendous pressures financially.  The soaring health costs we are all experiencing are not necessarily translating into increased remuneration to providers and health care organizations.  This can result in employees feeling less valued when I don't think that's the case - rather that the industry itself is struggling.

pros: CCF is a decent place to start a career. I was given the opportunity to learn a lot about my occupation. The health insurance, 403(b) matching + pension, and PTO system (28 days for the first 5 years) was very generous.
cons:
The salaries are below the market rate for my position. Merit raises are minimal (~2%). After 3 years, I learned that a fresh college graduate made more than I did at the time! My manager indicated that I do not deserve a larger raise despite strong experience and exceptional performance reviews. 

Additionally, management did not seem to take employee concerns seriously. A colleague bullied many people in my department. Despite numerous reports from many different people, it did not seem like any changes were made. 

The vision insurance is not great and did not save me money after considering the premiums.

pros:
I enjoyed the paycheck (even though not competitive).  

I stopped working there.

Good people to work with (coworkers)
cons:
Management is clueless, not from them being incompetent but rather the rules of the organization from the top

Attendence point system does not allow for real illnesses.  Doctor's notes do not excuse absences (ironic?)

Engagement focus was out of control. Just hire good workers instead of evaluating workers engagement all the time.

The clinic is too big.  I felt isolated and unable to enhance my career there.

pros: Very strong connection with the business and great HR business partners.  TA has worked hard to have a strong presence in the hospital and not just be an offsite entity. This has helped individuals truly learn the needs of the business and provide top talent.
cons: Too much turnover within the team, management in TA has not figured out how to retain employee's for much longer than 2-3yrs. The budget seems to be fairly unstable and there are a lot of scares around job security (potentially outsourcing recruitment).

review_title: Good benefits and learning opportunities, but salary is a little low
pros: Pretty good benefits, especially if you go to CC doctors. 403b with employer match, along with a pension. Give some education assistance and was encouraged to take classes. There were also opportunities to learn new things and get involved in special projects if you were interested. We were offered learning opportunities to expand our knowledge on equipment, medical procedures, or anything that was suggested from the group.
cons: Pay is a little low especially for engineers and the annual raises usually don't even cover the cost of living. Management (Clinical Engineering) would change their mind often which would cause extra work. Some decisions that seemed simple would take months to be made and usually turned into something more complicated than it truly was.

job_title: Administrative Program Coordinator in Cleveland, OH
pros: Diversity is celebrated & respected. The Cleveland Clinic has been successful by creating  wellness advocates in their employees. The majority of the employees are happy or satisfied with their work environment and feel that the organization cares about their wellbeing. The internal system (HR talent management, Complete Wellness of the mind, body and soul, our dining choices) the company knows we spend more time at work than at home and the main campus is had truly become a great work environment.
cons:
As an employee, the financial challenges in the US healthcare system has been hard to handle (e.g., healthcare reform). 
Out of 3 of the largest healthcare systems, Cleveland Clinic remains the most conservative.

review_title: Not recommended for people who don't like dealing with bureaucracy.
pros: It looks good to have the clinic on your resume. It pays better than most for jobs that don't require education. They don't ask a lot out of you. Tons of people easily skate by doing next to nothing. Great benefits and lots of paid time off.
cons: Upper management is incompetent more often than not. They put doctors in charge of everything, but guess what, doctors aren't good at everything! Shocker!!! If you are a low level employee they make sure to remind you of that everyday by treating you accordingly. Everyday I worked there I heard people talk about getting out. It all just depends on what department you are in.

review_title: IT is a great place to be.
pros: The Clinic is a fun place to work.  The people employed here are more than qualified to do their job.  You do get plenty of time off when needed and you are able to pretty much work where you qualify to work.
cons: Behind the times in technology as far as computers are concerned.  Exempt salary employees get treated like dirt at some times.  Raises are very small if you get one at all.  It's easy to get lost in the shuffle here.  There is too much work for the amount of people in IT.  Industry avg. is 250 computer per administrator, we currently have about 400 per.  Bad neighborhood.

pros: I enjoyed my time at Fairview and I do recommend it as a workplace. There is a strong sense of public service at this large nonprofit, and there is a lot of innovation in the IT organization as a result of perennially tight budgets combined with the rapidly advancing technology of health care.  Employees were some of the nicest folks I've worked with. Also, great medical benefits as long as you use Fairview hospitals, which are some of the best and located all over the area.
cons: Ultimately I left due to the low salary. For my experience level I was making drastically less than I could in a for-profit company.

job_title: Pot Doctoral Research Fellow in Cleveland, OH
pros: large facility with nice decoration and advertisements.
cons: low salary, harassing environment, poor career development, highly political.

job_title: Surgical Fee Coder in Cleveland, OH
pros: Steady Paycheck. Good Health Insurance.
cons: Clicquish environment, poor management, low raises, lower pay than one would expect in certain areas, long hours, very little encouragement or even training for that matter. They throw you into a job where the employees ignore you, management berates you, the pay sucks, slackers who’ve been there for years act haughty. On top of that the commute isn’t pleasant, parking is atrocious, and personal safety is a big issue. My advice? Keep your head down, don’t make the slackers look bad, suck up to management, and never complain. Otherwise find a job elsewhere.

pros: The Clinic strives to be the leader in healthcare innovation while keeping the patient experience as their primary focus.
cons: The Clinic's size can make it difficult to respond quickly and to implement change.  The organization struggles with the need to remain flexible and open to technological opportunities while managing a huge infrastructure and employee base.

job_title: IT Operations Manager in Cleveland, OH
pros: The Cleveland Clinic is a world class organization and a leader in the healthcare field. It consistently produces positive outcomes for it clients. The organization promotes creativity and the ability to ascend to the leadership ranks, by studying the leaders and following the roadmap provided.
cons: As a person who spent 15 of my 17 years in the middle management ranks, I believe the one negative that I would share is that due to the size of the organization middle management tends to be not very develop to produce positive outcomes with their span of control.  Instead of developing their teams they tend to spend too much time being policy correct.

review_title: Great Organization - If I ever left I would certainly consider returning
pros: We have the opportunity to work with some of the brightest minds in the world.  The culture is of innovation & questioning everything to make improvements, fearless leadership into the unknown to drive the industry, not respond to the industry.  The relationships are professional & respectful, partnership & collegial at all levels.  No one pulls a "I'm a Harvard grad MD" card.  We work as a team, a unit.  The patient population & the employee base is international..it's like working at the UN...very culturally sensitive, respectful & very interesting.  We have great benefits including great health care coverage.  Work/life balance is respected.
cons: The salaries are not very competitive & it's hard to nudge your salary up because of all the tiers/structure given such a large organization.

job_title: PAS Financial Counselor in Independence, OH
pros:
Large company, tons of benefits, huge networks come out of it. 

Cleveland Clinic is a really great company if you're working in the hospital, but behind the scenes is utter madness. I liked the company and the people; they were all very supportive and nice, but I'm not entirely sure if I could give them a lot of plus's besides that.
cons: Management is trying its best, but financial areas are understaffed, processes are incredibly slow and most of your day will be spent arguing with insurance companies on the phone. Pay is really good, so don't discount that. Cleveland Clinic will pay you well.

review_title: Company experience can vary in departments-every dep't like a separate company with separate rules.
pros: Can learn from others when permitted to learn from others. Advancement opportunities for those who are in tight with management.
cons: Separate rules and policies for each individual department...per supervisor or manager which can limit learning and advancement opportunities. Depends on the luck of what department you are located in on if your experiences are positive or negative. Mine happens to be the negative due to poor supervisor leadership and making up rules and regulations as they go along. First couple years I had great reviews and great work relationships, now since management changes...no growth opportunities and what was acceptable then is no longer acceptable now.

job_title: Patient Care Nursing Assistant (PCNA) in Cleveland, OH
pros: Benefits, PTO, double holiday pay
cons: Not enough staff. High turn over on pcna's. Sometimes the only pcna on the floor and the nurses do not help you. Always 12 to 16 patients to one pcna every night. Nurse do not take any as primary. Talk down to as if your stupid. If your not part of float pool they still float you every day to other floors. Sitting with patients that want to physically harm you or verbally abuse you. Paying to park

review_title: Don't do it! You'll regret it.
pros: Decent pay and benefits. Great people, great patients, nice facilities. Diverse work areas to broaden you knowledge base and experience.
cons: Horrible unqualified managers and upper echelon. I never felt that the company was truly vested in me as a provider even though I did whatever was asked of me and then some. When you genuinely have a concern the management doesn't care. This applies to the low man on the totem pole up to the physicians. Strongly discourage anyone from working here.

review_title: Unhappy employees result in unhappy patient satisfaction.
job_title: Health Unit Coordinator in Cleveland, OH
pros: It's a job in the health-care field for an organization that is perceived to be world-class.  It looks good on a resume.
cons: The patients are treated in a "world class" way but the employees are overlooked.  The hospital system recently took away benefits, including premium pay, yet expects employees to give more and more hours without incentive.  The hospital where I work is chronically short-staffed affecting patient safety.  It's not ok for a nurse to work a double shift to cover up the hospital's inability to attract employees.  Time off is punished with a punitive points system and management doesn't care if you have balance in your life involving your job and your home life.

pros: Great benefits and pay, tuition reimbursement is decent, great flexibility for medical appointments, work with great medical staff/physicians who will mentor.
cons: Not great for providing ADA workplace accommodations, administration moves at a snail's pace, sometimes work understaffed or without properly functioning equipment  due to "budget"which negatively affects patient care. There is a lot of ambiguity surrounding actual Cleveland Clinic policies and things that were just made up and mistaken for Cleveland Clinic policy. Also, the PTO system is horrible  if you have a chronic medical condition or children.

review_title: Avoid if you are a Nurse
pros: Benefits and tuition reimbursement
cons:
You will not be respected as a Nurse. I have worked at three hospital systems. The Clinic was the worst to work at. I am so relieved not to work there. They are “at will” and will throw an RN under the bus in a heartbeat. You are just a body and easily replaced. Don’t think they care either! This is a doctors hospital. 

This starts off as if you don’t pass the PBDS, you are let go. If your manager does not like how you are doing in your 90 day orientation, you are let go. There is a high demand and a very high turnover rate at the Clinic for nurses. Metro and UH are better choices for nurses in Cleveland. The Clinic is not a nurses hospital.

review_title: MIDDLE OF THE ROAD, LOOKING FOR A WAY OUT
pros: Many locations within the system to work.  Only company still employing people in the area.
cons: Management needs to be overhauled - too stuck in their ways.  No encouragement to upgrade skills by dept mgt or HR dept staff.

review_title: Try to stay away until you can obtain a higher position if you want to be treated well.
job_title: Patient Dining Associate in Cleveland, OH
pros: Some incentives are good if you're full time or make enough money. Some employees are nice and grateful to each other. They are a lot of smiles and greetings whether you are a stranger or not.
cons: Parking rates increase yearly (but no one's responsible for what happens to your car while parked.) Depending on what position you're in management is rude and ungrateful. Some doctors can be rude to other employees. Higher positions always want to tell on lower positions when they won't bend their rules for them.

pros: Not one pro to working for the clinic!
cons: You work in fear everyday! If you walk in front of the right person on the wrong day, forget it you will lose your job! They will fight your unemployment too! They do not care that you are a single parent! that you were a dedicated worker of theirs for years! They do not care if a family member dies they will try to force you to work and have you take your bereavement at another time! They do not even deserve a star! not even a half of one!

pros: Good health insurance and benefits
cons: Dealing with doctors and long time employees with big egos is not pleasant. You need a tough skin to work here. They don't like new employees coming into their small world. You have to use your PTO for everything (sick days, appointments,holidays come out of your PTO, sent home for lack of work, etc.) You get points if your sick and call off, or leave work due to emergency, if weather is bad and can't get out of your driveway etc.

job_title: Administrative Assistant III in Cleveland, OH
pros: Pay Benefits, Atmosphere Parking Opportunity
cons: The drive is difficult, paying for parking is expensive, insurance is expensive, people get overworked, reviews are completely subjective and performance is not tracked (good or bad) until the time of the review

job_title: Postdoctoral Research Fellow in Cleveland, OH
pros: Freedom of work and freedom of thoughts. Lots of NIH funding - one of the best in the USA in terms of research funding. Have defined career paths for the postdocs to research associateship, stuff scientist or even to assistant stuff position. Lots of internal reward program for good science. In short one of the best place to do post doctoral work. As a city Cleveland is very much affordable. The job also comes with exceptional benefit package. One of the best health insurance coverage in one of the nations topmost health system.
cons: Its more patient oriented so the main focus is not in basic science science research. However its exceptional in translational research.

pros: Good insurance and pay rate, job security and continuing education benefits. They are a teaching hospital (magnet) so are more open to new ideas and evidence based practices.
cons: I felt that the position was too high stress for a new nurse. The training system was poorly thought out, Communication was poor between the floor nurses and the educational manager. It seemed the floor nurses were not interested or resented having to bother with the new hires.

pros:
-Excellent benefits for an American company
-Challenging environment
-Name recognition
-Flexible hours, overtime, PTO (but hospitals have few holidays)

There's a focus on continuing education with a subsidy for certain degrees at Case Western.  High impact research means publications and connections in academia internationally. 

Most everyone you work with has PhD which is a pro and a con.
cons:
Many of the usual pressures of academic jobs:
-Competitive atmosphere
-Intense work.  
-Flexible hours translates to working all the time.  Thinking about it all the time.
-Pay is bad 

I would only recommend to people who are very serious about pursuing a scientific career.  Make sure you have your life together first too!  Balance can fly right out the window, but it doesn't have to.

pros: Clinical staff and Doctors are nice. Good benefits but that's pretty much it.
cons: This is the WORST place to work for. This is jail to be exact. Ever since they changed management, its gone downhill. They have way too many managers and supervisors and not enough staff. The work load is ridiculous and the pay is definitely not worth it. The supervisor/managers have their favorites and treat the true hardworking people like trash. There is NO support from management either and they always focus on the negative on people rather than the positive. I would never recommend this place to anyone, not even my worst enemy.

pros: They give you the impression that they really are concerned about their employees. They support their employees to seek higher education with financial assistance.
cons: They pound their culture into  you with annual exams, you are late and docked for being 1 minute late. That 1 minute can get you terminated. If you need to go to emergency and you are not admitted. You will be charged $100. dollars per visit. Raises are determined by evaluations that could be very unfair depending on the person doing your evaluation.

job_title: Patient Service Representative in Independence, OH
pros: Rewarding to see that just the small part you play in their Cleveland Clinic experiences really makes their days; job security; great pay for what you do; you feel like you "belong" with your coworkers; laid-back environment; I love my job and I feel like this is a perfect start for someone who wants to continue to grow within the Cleveland Clinic; you don't have to be medically trained to have a good job at the clinic
cons: Patients will take out their frustrations on you just the same they would on the nurse; can be a bit overwhelming at times, depending upon department; difficulty getting approved time off because managers are in charge of staffing entire buildings, not just your department

review_title: Hospital is highly ranked, Lerner is another story.
pros: Great cores, some great people, funding, many seminars. Not super pressured, a lot of time drinking coffee and walking around.
cons: Some horrible people, research is not the priority regardless what Crile wanted (Serpil even said this during an LRI townhall) , slow for change, parking isn't great, some PIs have absolutely no idea what they are doing (typically an MD), and you are second rate unless you are a physician. So I left and I am much happier at my new position. The main campus is flawless until you walk into Lerner where they stop caring but at least we have colored walls and energetic art whereas the rest of the campus is mental institution white.

pros: You will be employed and you will have good benefits.  Like me, you might meet any number of wonderful doctors and employees.
cons: Absolutely a mess.  Many managers have the right credentials but they are awful leaders.  There is absolutely no career planning for non clinical employees.  The Clinic is so stratified with doctors at the top and everyone else at the bottom--and believe me, they let you know.  Doctors, Administrators throwing temper tantrums, swearing, threatening people, acting like mental cases.  It's the truth.  More often than not, very unprofessional business atmosphere.  The doctors and nurses are scheduled like they work in a factory.  The pay is awful.

pros: Flexible hours, great manager, inspiring place to be, room for growth (encouraged)
cons: I always feel like "just a number"... but that's corporate. Lots of paperwork, reviews, evaluations, etc. They can call you off and never even tell you. Showed up once and said no need for me, had to drive hour home. Called me off for the first 8 hours of my shift another time and had to go in for my last 4 hours or take call of penalty... 2 hour round trip drive to work 4 hours. Doesn't happen often but I have experienced it.

review_title: Great place to work, great benefits, mostly great people
pros:
*Pension (Crazy right?)
*Great Health Insurance
*401B
*A lot of variety, many locations
*Ability to work with people inside and outside the organization
*Many places to advance if you don't want to stay with EHS
*Flexibility
cons:
*Dental is okay
*Depending on what your focus is, a lot of desk work
*All older men in the department. I had some issues with being a young female.
*Hard to move up without degrees, certifications, etc (They really like letters after your name)
*Kind of hard to get a straight answer

review_title: I learned a great deal from this company.
job_title: Patient Service Representative in East Cleveland, OH
pros: The income potential is grand and you will learn a great deal about the medical field.
cons: This company is not always good about taking care of their own employees or the poor people in the poor neighborhoods.  They had a wonderful hospital in the city of E. Cleveland. It was a trauma 1 hosptal which was located in the inner city where there was a great deal of elderly tax payers with health concerns and a great deal of crime resulting in trauma medical emergency care.  They not only closed the hospital but tore it down!

job_title: Appointment Center Representative in Chagrin Falls, OH
pros:
Large place, could be easily lost and become a number, lots of jobs open across the company`
Worked for the company for over 10 years and seen changes that were well intended like the smoking cessation ( I used to be a smoker too so I know both sides) 
Many locations throughout the greater Cleveland area...
cons:
HR extremely slow to respond and hiring process is long and without updates.When a posting a listed , list the HR rep so internal staff can follow up on position that might attract them !
We all have jobs to do and expected to do it well ...

job_title: Cardiac Monitor Tech in Cleveland, OH
pros: Flexible Schedule, Great Benefits, Easy job to learn and maintain with continuing education, Good tuition reimbursement options, some of the workers are great
cons: Micromanagers, management plays favorites, other than that, only 1 or 2 managers actually care about the workers, the rest just care if the spaces are filled and try to get anyone they can in trouble so they can suck up to the supervisor of the unit, barely any breaks during a 12 hour shift.

review_title: The Cleveland Clinic is great organization for inspiring professional and personal growth.
pros: The benefits are excellent. The training environment has great potential when properly funded and utilized. The Cleveland Clinic provides an environment that will drive and motivate individuals to seek personal and professional growth.
cons: At times, employees and/or their departments will be on the wrong end of a business decision. This leads to frequent adaption to new policies, protocols, and initiatives to meet employment performance criteria and patient needs. The education benefits program was a huge plus, however recently funding for the program was decreased (for non-nursing degrees) because of cost repositioning efforts. Employees who were already enrolled in the program were not grandfathered into the original reimbursement when they signed up.

review_title: A very difficult transition with no "on boarding' process at all and no indoctrination as to the working protocols.
pros: It was amazing to witness the healing and recovery work from catastrophic illness. The experience enlightened me as to the challenges of administering care
cons:
-The politics
Rule by innuendo
no forum for conflict resolution
-Costs before comprehensive care
-Sporadic infrastructure applications
-Consider deferred salary structure to keep incomes from tax devastation

pros: Well respected in my role, I was able to move up without a degree, friendly coworkers, big on teamwork, staff is excellent in emergencies. Orientation was plentiful. Good PTO and I've heard benefits are great. Management in my dept made a true effort to implement ideas the staff had.
cons: The attendance policy is basically hard and fast. If you are PRN it is extremely strict no matter how many hours you are putting in and if you do not get a warning, they will just fire you.

review_title: Great on a CV, hard to break in to staff positions unless you come from outside of CCF.
job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Cleveland, OH
pros: Top flight facilities and research opportunities.  World class researchers.  Cleveland is actually a pretty cool city.  Very affordable housing and nice parks.
cons: M.D. staff are treated as godly.  But since they pay the bills, I guess its fair.  Grad students get paid nothing, as do post-docs.  Might be a bit jaded since I worked professionally before cutting pay by 75% to come back for PhD.  Staff PhD's - some have 'it', some seem to be treading water until they get forced to move on.

review_title: Inovative Health Care Organization with great benefits
job_title: Systems Analyst III in Cleveland, OH
pros: Benefits are very good.  The company reaches out to the comunity.  The core values are honorable.
cons: I work in IT.  The Clinical areas hire their own technology support.  Often the clinical people are not technical and the project managers don't understand the stakeholders.  IT employees are overworked and under valued.  There is little or no training available to grow your skill sets.  This is a VERY political company.  You have to learn to watch your back here.

job_title: Public & Media Relations in Cleveland, OH
pros: Opportunity to learn and to hone one's skills. Work can be interesting at times.
cons: Higher than average turnover in the department. Director encouraged in-fighting among her team rather than a collaborative environment. Thus, much competition among team members to get noticed or promoted. No structure - department was run more or less by the "seat of the director's pants." Additionally, the department's director was more inclined to throw anybody on her team under the bus if it meant saving face.

pros: CCF is very organized and a good community.  Their research is top notch, and working as a researcher will open doors for you.
cons: The environment is very high pressure as far as winning grants for research and publishing.  Some PIs are good at this, and have no problem doing well.  Others are not good at it, and tend to blame everyone around them for their own shortcomings. Unfortunately, the system at CCF tends to enable this behavior rather than punishing it.

review_title: You can feel good about working here
pros: The pay is good, the benefits are good, the perks (yoga) are nice.  Generally co-workers are nice.  The mission of the organization is something you can take pride in.  A big, stable corporation that is doing OK in spite of the economic downturn.
cons: Not confident in competency of senior management.  Tendency to hire outsiders rather than promote from within, but there are exceptions.  Too much politics, which creates stress.  Constant health-oriented messages may be annoying to some people (re: healthy eating, not smoking, exercising).  Constant push for "employee engagement" is also annoying.

pros: Management is sometimes not on the same page with employees.  overall is has been a great learning expiernce.  I have met alot of new and interesting people in the process
cons: since a month ago we had many problems regarding parking.  also the do not take the surgical technologist profession seriously we are group in the housekeeping department.  but we must carry a degree and become certified as well

review_title: I enjoy that everyday is different for me.
pros:
Constantly learning new things.
Tuition reimbursement.
health benefits.
opportunity to advance.
continuing education opportunities.
employee camraderie.
gratitude when helping others.
cons:
The neighborhood.
Raises don't seemed based on merit--everyone does the same job and gets the same increase but some may work harder than others.
Paying to park.

job_title: Medical Technologist in East Cleveland, OH
pros: Decent pay rate, World class facility, many different hospitals to choose for employment, opportunities for educational advancement with employer funding available
cons: Organization too large to provide individual attention (to employees), understaffed, overworked, too much is expected too often, co-workers unfriendly, unwelcoming, clique-ish, not enough time and patience given to training new hires

pros: The work-life balance is really good! If you want a stable job then this is a good place to work. This is a great place to start your career and learn the basics. The health benefits are great along with the retirement benefits.
cons: There is not much room for advancement or career growth. They stress career development but no one takes it seriously. The pay is not up to standards.

review_title: More than 20 years experience in the medical field.
job_title: Patient Services Reresentative in Weston, FL
pros: Excellent salary and benefits. Chance for advancement and additional education is available to all. Many extra benefits most companies do not offer are available with the Cleveland Clinic.
cons: Not many just the usual gossips and lazy employees that seem to know how to get away with murder. I can't really add more but I will add that sometimes these lazy employees get away with murder because they are friends with management.

job_title: Patient Care Nursing Assistant (PCNA) in Cleveland, OH
pros: Willing to work with schedules for students, great work environment, (I work in the PICU), focused highly on patient care as well as employee education. Benefits kick in the day you're hired.
cons: little to no overtime, have to be in a position a year before any kind of lateral movement. While accruing PTO, new hires can't use it for the first 90 days.

review_title: It all depends on the department
pros:
Good Benefits: inexpensive health insurance, $ for degrees, free health clubs
Trying to change culture
Opportunities to change position (when not in a hiring freeze)
Flexible hours (depending on department and manager)
Healthcare is a growing industry
Working for a world class organization (don’t discount this)
cons:
Some departments are toxic (it all depends on the Department Chair, and the culture they create)
Doctors come first (but a 60 hours week is standard), clinical workers come second, and non-clinical are below stepchildren
There does not seem to be much oversight at top levels of management, but at lower levels micro-management thrives
Many people of color appear to be discriminated against

job_title: Health Unit Coordinator in Cleveland, OH
pros:
The floor as a whole is very helpful, teamwork minded, and mindful of their co-workers. I constantly hear RN's asking each other if they need help. Being part of The Cleveland Clinic Way and knowing that you are truely helping people, heal and feel better.
I'm learning more patients when dealing with medical staff
Charity Involvment, good compentition between floors
cons:
Healthcare in itself can be challanging. Lack of support from Managment and other hospital floors.
The estrogen overload can be slightly unbearable at times, with the nagging, complaining, and attitudes
Working understaff and doing more work to compensate for the change in health care; which I feel is wrong because we are losing the meaning of the care in health.

review_title: Patient Service Representative and Ins Verification, many other duties above & beyond m job title
job_title: Patient Service Representative in West Palm Beach, FL
pros: Great benefits and decent salary. There are many other perks to working at Cleveland Clinic. One is the "store" and being able to purchase a new laptop  also your benefits kick in the day you start work!?
cons: Crazy point system assessed for time off. I can understand it for the people that abuse sick time but to give someone this point system when they never abuse time is purely ridiculous!!!

job_title: Patient Service Representative in Avon, OH
pros: The great team I work with, the medical benefits.
cons: Terrible management, Nepotism,  having to use PTO for holidays that they force you to take. Terrible pay for the responsibilities that are placed upon you.

review_title: Can be a great place needs some changes
job_title: Assistant to the Chair in Cleveland, OH
pros: Great benefits.  Flex time and work from home options.
cons: Supervision structure is not great for administrative assistants, coordinators and secretaries.  Review structure is also not the best.  And moving up and advancing is hard.  New administrative people make what babysitters make and it doesn't get much better.

pros: A highly respected name-brand facility in the country. Many employers/recruiters take particular notice when CCF is listed on a resume. A wonderful facility for medical innovations and patient treatments. Great training experience, Magnet status.
cons: Very aloof attitude of management staff. There are cliques throughout all the departments; if you are not part of particular ones, you are an outsider (good luck). My morning cardiac workout was walking from the parking garage to my floor!

pros: Caring, Compassionate co-workers, Growth opportunities., Tutuion reimbursment,  so many locations there is sure to be one close to home
cons:
The Enterprise (this is what the clinic calls itself) seems to value doctors and nurses more than other employees. Not sure about other areas, but in NE Ohio we're given 6 or 7 holidays major holidays, but there's a catch, you have to use YOUR PTO to cover them,  so hopefully you're scheduled to work or else you lose
Health benefits are expensive.

review_title: Good for a resume stop, but don't make it your career
pros: Great benefits, great people make the job.
cons: If you miss working in the 1970s, then go work for Cleveland Clinic - it's like stepping back in time. Management would rather let talented workers walk than fire bad managers. Career pathing is non-existent. They pay lip service to being a great place to work but don't allow flex time, part time or job sharing. Doctors are treated as gods and are allowed to make business decisions that make no sense.

pros: Work with good people, pathologists who are tops in their fields yet incredibly down to earth, significant autonomy, good benefits, proud to be part of an organization that does such good work, reasonably good pay. Superior physician executives and sales director. Overall, I love this job.
cons: Issues with how revenue is reported creates radical highs and lows (which affects monthly bonus), very aggressive annual goals, frequent changes in direction makes it difficult to focus on long-term territory growth.

pros: I worked as a Research Technician in the Lerner Research Institute for three years. The Cleveland Clinic takes very good care of their employees, and I always felt that my work was appreciated. I was proud to work for a company that is on the cutting edge of medical research and was well-respected among the global community.
cons: The pay wasn't that great, but I felt like the benefits and the joy of working there more than made up for it.

pros: There are many discount programs for venues around cleveland. The benifits are not bad and the people I work with are wonderful.
cons: The clinic almost comes close to a cult. They really do not care what their employees feel or think and they treat employee's with handicaps really horrible. The pay also is not world class and you are just your employee number and nothing else. The wellness program is also a huge joke and just a way for the clinic to save on insurance.

pros: Good Benefits:  Health insurance, 403 b and a 3% contribution to a pension
cons: Pay is low, especially in large departments like billing and revenue.  They know half the people there will never find a better job, so why pay them more.  It sucks for people with meaningful degrees who use these jobs as a door opener.  For a business casual environment prepare to see a lot of sandals.

pros: Benefits are good, learning center has plenty of classes to take, wellness taken very seriously
cons: Layers upon layers of management.  It felt the C suite was very transparent until recently.  Now everything seems shrouded in mystery and employees are left wondering what is coming next.  Flow of information varies in each department.  I learn more about what is going outside my department than on the inside.  Recent early retirement buyouts and layoffs are leaving some employees feeling uncertain about the future of the clinic and their jobs.

pros: Great benefits, decent pay considering health insurance covers so much, tuition reimbursement, some growth opportunities, emphasis on top-notch patient care, state-of-the-art treatments and technology, 12-hour shifts, and some of my coworkers are great.
cons: There are too many politics. Too many moody and lazy employees; there needs to be more of an emphasis on finding top-notch, hard-working, compassionate employees. If the Clinic put half the effort into hiring such PCNAs, dietary employees, housekeepers, etc. as they do with higher-up positions (RNs, NPs, MDs, SWs, RTs, etc.), I wouldn't be quitting, patients would be more satisfied, and other employees wouldn't be scurrying out of the doors. Come on! This isn't science; it's common sense. I'm all for CCF being an EQUAL opportunity employer; that doesn't mean you hire a copious amount of lazy, unappreciative, apathetic employees. The Clinic needs a massive employee restructuring! I should have to see a McDonald's employee stuffing chicken nuggets in her mouth and another dancing while I am waiting to order a coffee. Not to mention, I am sick of floating at least once a week to different parts of the hospital where I have to deal with even more jerks in addition to working on a unit I'm unfamiliar with! As a RN, it is hard to rely the supportive staff. I have pharmacy techs chewing gum in my ear when I call for a medication, hanging up on me, and not sending the medications my patients need! These managers need to tighten their reins and fire any employee not contributing to the Cleveland Clinic's "world-class care"/patient-first mission. This point-system is also killing me! I called off four times over the course of an entire year and have almost reach my point max. In addition, I provided a possible revision to this system and was simply blown off.

pros: Great benefits including paid time off and knowledgable co-workers. We work with some of the best doctors in the world that sub specialize in different problems and we have all of the state of the art diagnostic equipment.
cons: Too many managers who are unable to perform the jobs of those they manage. Administration expects us to see more patients with less caregivers and no overtime.

pros: They offer very competitive pay. Offers a lot of flexibility. Great opportunities for future growth within the company. I love my job.
cons: One thing I don't like about the Cleveland Clinic is the parking situation. They have me parking at a very far lot and it seems dangerous at night. It is a tiny lot and there are not any other employees walking with me at night. I have tried to change it but it's a no go.

job_title: RN Staff Nurse in Cleveland, OH
pros: Great experience and diverse patient caseload.  Good starting point in any medical career;  and always good to come back to work for.
cons: Too large at times in regard to the simplicity of basic excellent one to one bedside care that at times cannot compete to smaller community hospitals.

job_title: HIM Coder Trainee in Cleveland, OH
pros: None, HIM should focus of obtaining a process where they could screen potential coders other than HR. Along with having a broader qualifications to being a coder such as prior clinical experience as allied health professional or MD/DO knowledge set should be considered experience for being an HIM Coder I, I, II, or IV.
cons:
Low pay. Based upon cost of living and commuting. HR wants certain individuals to only work for 12.45$/hr?!?!?!?!?!?!
What is the point of acquiring higher education when I can work elsewhere for the same amount and be GM at a restaurant chain? CCF gains monetary funds from various sources yet can not fairly compensate their coding department?

review_title: In the beginning things were pretty good. This could be a great place to work once again.
pros: Unfortunately with this management regime the only rewarding part of this job is the paycheck and very good health insurance. Yearly climate control is a huge plus, meaning not working out in the weather.
cons: Difficult managers who manage through the use of discipline and fear of losing your job. Write ups & Corrective Actions are given out unfairly with very little, or no thought of the consequences that any easily averted action causes the average worker. For one, it does eliminate any possibility for a raise, no chance of moving to another department for at least a year. If you happen to be taking college courses, tuition reimbursement is taken away for a year. This place can and will be a great place to work once again, but the mindset of discipline needs to be looked at seriously. I am only speaking about the Facilities Dept. I suppose a regime change is what it will take to turn this ship around.

pros: getting the chance to work with different types of people with different types of diseases not seen anywhere else--there is a huge chance of being involved with someof the smartest people in the business at every turn----however due to the hectic nature of the job due to volume of patients seen, it can be very overwhelming and an overall exhausting experience fo the employee
cons: since they are such a huge operation, easy to be overlooked----also there is the attitude of "we are the cleveland clinic and it is our way or the  highway"

review_title: The worst place to work by far.
job_title: O R Division in Cleveland, OH
pros: The insurance was cheap compared to others.
cons: Horrible management, Terrible CEO (Toby Cosgrove), traffic is unbelievable at the main campus, rude employees and stuck up doctors.

pros: The Cleveland Clinic is a great name to add to your resume and to gain experience in one of the "leaders" within the sickcare industry. The employees and the nurses do really care about the patients.
cons: Such a political and toxic environment. Their motto is "Patients First", but I really didn't feel like senior leadership felt that way. They kept on repeating the message as a propaganda to motivate employees and market to the patients, but the bottom line is that they only focused on profits. Salaries are very low and overall motivation is rock bottom.

pros: Great people to work with. Love the pts I deal with the manager is great at the family health centers and you do not have to pay to part
cons: Really wish we got better raises but better then making minimum wage  I don't the people higher up that change stuff really understand the work flow of what we do every day.. For family insurance it is 200 a pay kinda crazy but good insurance

review_title: This brand doesn't pay my bills
job_title: Systems Analyst II in Cleveland, OH
pros: Beautiful safe campus & multiple locations . I have always had nice office/cube with state of the are equipment. IT can work remote a few times a week. 2% annual merit increase is almost a guarantee for all employees. Some annual increases have been as high as 6.75 % with an exceptional review.
cons: Low pay & not a lot of opportunity if you do not have a degree. It is expected that employees appreciate being a part of the CCF brand but brand recognition doesn't pay my bills.

review_title: Pay is good, yet micromanagement isn't worth the Stress
job_title: Patient Service Representative in Cleveland, OH
pros: The pay is a lot higher than other hospitals in the area. Co-workers are fun to work with and Helping Patients.
cons:
The point system is very strict. No sick days for you or your family. If your even one minute late clocking in you get a point, yet the managers who are salaried dont have to swipe in are late every day.
Your the one the patients yell at when their doctor walks in 30 minutes late.
Doctors and PAs can be very mean and talk down to you.

review_title: Great Learning Experience bu career ladder is not defined
pros:
Great place to learn ad practice your craft.
Coworkers really make the day or night go smoother thru team work and camaderie
Depending on which campus you work at it never surpasses the opportunities at the "Main Campus"
cons: Upper management more specifically the director of the department might be encouraged to stall your educational growth which would lead you to better internal opportunities just for their benefit of keeping you on their staff a little while longer.....

review_title: Great place to work at the time
pros: Wonderful coworkers, life/work balance, flexible WFH as long as you worked hard and performed well.  Just be sure the position you apply for is not earmarked for outsourcing.
cons: The outsourcing of their (much of their) IT was force-fed by their top exec at the time.  Mass exodus of very good IT talent.  Very bad timing, right in the middle of a major hospital acquisition and systems integration.  Painful.  Not sure how this is working out still.

pros: There are a lot of great people who work at CCF.  Great benefits.
cons: The health insurance has degraded since I started 5 years ago.  Unfortunately, there is often management roulette - sometimes great management, sometimes horrible management.  Figuring out  which department falls into which management bucket is the tricky part of working at CCF.  Work life balance is not important to management.

job_title: Senior Research Technologist in Cleveland, OH
pros: Flexible hours (research), health center, one of the few biotech opportunities in northern OH
cons: Institution doesn't support basic science research as much as clinical; more interested in saving $ than supporting research. Spent a ton of money on "engagement"- yet really never followed through. It's all about "looking" like the greatest employer than actually BEING one. (i.e.- if a PI brings in $$- then they can treat their employees as nasty as they like). I have a great boss- but many PI's are not respectful.

pros: Great employee benefits and discounts. tuition reimbursement. I hear that it's much better at Cleveland Clinic Ohio.
cons: Not a competitive salary. Not a supportive workplace. Management leads by intimidation. Rather than recognize people for going above and beyond and taking on additional duties to compensate for understaffing, employees are reprimanded and told what more they could have done. I've never worked for an organization that penalizes you for taking your PTO. It's crazy.

job_title: Patient Access Representative in Euclid, OH
pros: They have great benefits and they have so many different opportunities and so many different facilities and hospitals that it’s amazing. You can find a great job that pays great and they will take a chance and hire you with no experience and no referrals! You can grow with this company and they will pay for your education. If you leave you will want to go back eventually because of all the great opportunities available. You will work with some amazing people from all walks of life, they have amazing training classes that will help you feel confident in your position. Some hospitals have Starbucks inside them and the food is not bad at all. Overall I was satisfied with my time at CC and some of my coworkers did not want me to leave and tried talking me out of it. I enjoyed my job as a PAR and I would go back(in a different hospital of course.) They gave out free ice cream a meals on holidays and it was a warm and welcoming environment. They paid time and a half which was great! Choose your facility wisely though, because each has own there pros and cons like the parking at main campus versus free parking at the community hospitals. Also, size matters and I say you go where you know and feel comfortable. It’s a fast hiring and interview process. If you get the chance to be hired or rehired by this amazing company, stay and explore all your options before you quit because it’s the number 2 hospital in the country! Mark my words. And hopefully I will get rehired and be at the facility of my choice because I love this company and they stand by their mission, vision and values!!
cons: Very cliquish and some physicians have a superiority complex and make it hard for you to do your job in a timely fashion. The nurses have no disregard for PAR’s and patients are sometimes discharged without having the appropriate paper work signed and/ or their IDs and insurance cards. HR is a joke and they laugh at you when your expressing a concern to them about management and coworkers. Euclid hospital is experiencing budget cuts so they have PAR’s doing multiple job titles and they have you do on-the-job training and cross training to have you fulfill multiple roles and your expected to learn quickly and fill in when needed, no questions asked.  A lot of the employees have been there for YEARS and they are burnt out and that job is all they have and they take it out on new employees. There are also bedbugs in the hospital and you have they have it exterminated atleast once a week so it’s best to keep your belongings in your car or tied up and secured. I would’ve stayed if they had a different position open that wasn’t in the ER or if my manager would have let me transfer(which is two years) but every time I brought it up she would talk me out of it and give me a hard time. I was helping out at HC and all of a sudde they just stopped asking me help out and started ignoring me. It’s like a wild zoo at the Euclid and I think it may shut down soon just as Huron Hospital did.

review_title: Good place to work, but need to work in every hospital setting.
