pros: Compensation and benefits are good. Office space is adequate and technology is always seen as a very important aspect. You will have the latest and greatest equipment.
cons: Co-workers are generally displeased with their workload and working in a hospital setting is very depressing. Must be extremely conscious of germs as well.

pros:
My position was in the ER department so we stayed at a fast paced and stayed  mostly organized. Some days we had to work with patients independently and keep files completed for nurses assistant. 
I learned more about computer programs and office equipment. Received more education on insurance plans.
With interacting personally with registered  patient's here able to explain all there rights to privacy, HIPPA and insurance.
cons: office equipment would run slow. Prior Policies weren't completely explained to some patients and patient's family members. work schedule varied

pros: Friendly work environment and a great work life balance. This would be a good place to work once you've settled later in life and just want to collect a check.
cons: So much red tape that very little ever gets accomplished. Just on the floor I worked on I can count 5 different levels of management.

review_title: A great place to learn and beef up a resume
pros:
Amazing place to work with world class doctors and researchers
Lots of opportunities to socialize outside of work
GREAT benefits
cons:
Everything within the hospital system is VERY bureaucratic. 
Promotion is very slow (unless you are a doctor or PI)
Pay is below market
Surprisingly inflexible on hours (even taking 4 hours off to fight a traffic ticket took considerable effort).

review_title: Proud to work there, good teamwork
pros: People care about the work because it benefits patients, interesting work, cross team and department cooperation, lots of different technologies, top quality hospital, good benefits.
cons: Some bad managers, like most work places. Don't see the value some of their best team members bring to the table, let their power get to their heads or don't treat team members with respect.

review_title: It was a good entry level job.
pros: Positive environment. Great health benefits. Tuition reimbursement was amazing. However, I heard it was drastically reduced in the last couple of years.
cons: A lot of time is wasted on the politics and therefore things don't get done as quickly. Pay was low compared to the market. However, I couldn’t complain because I did not have a lot of experience coming into the job. Parking was horrible and expensive. I worked on the main campus which is not easily accessible coming in from the east side.

review_title: Medical Director, Global Medical Education, Medical Network & Physician Enterprise, Global Medical Marketing
pros: Teaching hospital which a mission is education those who serve. Institution focused on quality, innovations in medicine and surgery, latest medical technologies and world-class healthcare.
cons: Cleveland clinic in Weston, Florida is small hospital with just 150 beds which has been difficult to make advertisements and accommodate international patients. They need more beds in ICU to receive more patients in critical care from Central America and the Caribbean. All physicians are employed and it has been difficult to schedule more  patients and walk extra milies.

pros: Research and Learning environment, Helpful team of nurses, Friendly co workers, Good pay and benefits, Schedule made months in advance, adequate training program for new nurses
cons: Heavy workload, Management expects a lot from you, upper management rushes to fill beds quickly sometimes you can't get time for a break, No separate sick time to use,

pros: good new hire training.
cons: Rotating schedule 2/2 seems management still cannot figure out scheduling . some days overstaffed to where we need to call of 5-7 nurses and some days we are only three nurses staffed for 24 patients. Too many hands in one pot and not knowing what each is doing. Have to work minimum two years same position to move on to different area,( used to be one year). It is very discouraging, feels like being stuck in one place for two years before able to make a career move.

review_title: My experience has been rewarding and amazing.
pros: You get the chance to help people and make a difference everyday. You get to work for an amazing organization wuth some of the best people.
cons: There are no cons that I can think of.  you really have to love what you do in order to succeed in your job.

pros: Excellent Health Benefits!, Employee Perks in the Community, Health Programs, Gym or Curves Membership
cons: Low Pay, Staffing Issues, "Cost Re-positioning", Under qualified management, No raises

review_title: Great insurance and benefits -- that's about it!
job_title: Patient Service Representative in Weston, FL
pros:
Great Insurance Benefits
Retirement - Matches 3% with Fidelity
cons:
Dealing with the RUDE patient's who come in was definitely the hardest part of this job.  You would have a patient yelling in your face and shaking their fist in your face and you were made to deal with it and go above and beyond what you would do for a regular patient to make them happy. This was not acceptable in my mind.

There was room for growth -- but no raises to go with it.

Lack of communication between departments and between management.

pros: The People in our department are like a big family. Very friendly staff.
cons: No room for advancement at all. Try to pick up extra hours 7 months ago and were dragging their feet. Was promised a lead tech role and was then shot down.

pros: -Good Benefits, Intelligent Co-workers, State of the art technology, Great Morale in BME dept., Great for building connections in the medical and research fields
cons: Each experience is highly dependent upon your lab and the grants awarded to your primary investigator. Further schooling is often necessary for growth in research. Parking can be difficult, but it's understandable given that the Cleveland Clinic is a large hospital in a growing area.

pros: Just telling people you worked here sometimes get you in the door. The ambulatory surgery centers are really the best places to work.
cons: Better employees. A lot of bullying from other team members who did not want to share information because they feel like you will take their job. The Cleveland clinic is so big that you really are just a number. Any thoughts of going to human resources with a complaint about a hostile work environment is not taken seriously.

review_title: A fantastic place to build your career and stay for your 30 years.
job_title: Critical Care Paramedic in Cleveland, OH
pros: Competitive pay, untouchable benefits, they truly invest time in you. Good work culture, and they actually try to meet the standard of work-life balance.
cons: The clinical side of things are entirely and overly micromanaged. From what I hear on the floor, they have unrealistic standards.

review_title: Not an ideal place for researchers
pros: Excellent health benefits, work environment, research core services and support, collaboration among peers and labs, access to an enriched library and access to a wide array of research papers and journals
cons: Does not promote researchers in alternate career opportunities, poor guidance with regards to jobs in non academic areas, extremely stressful, low pays for researchers, if asked for a raise you may lose your job instead, poor funding situation for researchers.

review_title: Not the best option for RNs
pros:
* Benefits (health care, tuition reimbursement)
* Being able to put Cleveland Clinic on your resume
* Ability to apply to other positions after 1 year
* You'll see things you won't see at smaller hospitals
cons:
* Rigorous testing (physical, PBDS, EKG, etc) 
* Only $18/hr for new grads where other hospitals start at $24/hr +
* Pay for parking
* Cost cutting resulting in Increasingly unsafe patient:nurse ratios
* Punitive environment
* Rotating day/nights
* Unreasonable expectations and constant drilling on "patient satisfaction"

review_title: It's A Good Place to Work but...
pros:
Big company,plenty of advancement opportunities.
Decent health plan.
Industry leader.
cons:
Too many layers of management to get things done.
PTO (paid time off) could be better...workers are expected to use PTO for holidays, acts of god like snowstorms, power outages.  CC is the ONLY organization in Cleveland that expects employees to use PTO for acts of God.
Too many inexperienced manager that treat hourly staff like dirt.

pros: Efficient hospital. Facilities top notch. GME has good resources and is generally professional. Generally speaking, there is a sense of accountability. Overall, the organization is not dysfunctional.
cons: Very corporate feel. Hospital is overly dependent on residents. Education is often the second/third priority. Obsession over reputation and "customer service" leads to "VIP care" decisions rather than medically sound decisions. Pressure on physicians to see more and more patients leads to erosion of academic time.

review_title: The Clinic is a good place to work - plenty of benefits and investment in the employees.
job_title: Postdoctoral Research Fellow in Cleveland, OH
pros: The health plan is great for Postdoctoral Research Fellows, although I can't speak for other positions. There is also much effort invested in health initiatives - CCF gym memberships, farmer's markets, etc.
cons: Parking. Parking options are terrible and you waste a lot of time getting to and farm parking locations. Additionally, postdoctoral positions often allow for a flexible work schedule, but with the timing of seminars and workshops, it is often difficult to get out before 5, no matter how early you come.

pros: None as I can think of. Only salary is a bit better, may be. Only pros: they plant ORIGINAL indoor plants & trees, not the plastic ones.
cons:
Major Con: Don't expect any of your work request to be done before 2 months. Your lab desktop broke and you put up a "Heat ticket". Don't expect to get any response from them, in person or in email. Someone might show up after 2 months if you keep on writing follow up every week. That's pretty much same for every sort of work request you put up. 
 
Research institute-LRI is managed by same management, hence they never understand or agree on issues of LRI researchers. Dress code for lab- No Denims. 

Don't be surprised if you find cockroaches in your drawer and flies flying in the lab. Your lab may get to more than 78 F most often. That is normal. 

Your lab is so noisy due to the old Refrigerators of department on the alley way, that everyone in that room gets headache by 2pm of the day. You as well as your PI requests for solution. Nothing happens. by the way, I am sure the noise level decibel os higher than the standard to be considered Occupational hazard. 
Need to order a reagent of your choice which you things works good for you. You have to order and buy only the reagents which is available on the Lawson system. You can't order anything outside their database. You are lucky if you find alternative in their database. Forget about discount coupons you may have. You can't use that to save some money for your lab. You pay the fixed price on Lawson, which is the highest rate (not the Institutional rate  that is cheaper than MSRP).

Retirement benefits: You don't get any in the 1st year. From 2nd year only you are considered employee, hence get employee benefit. 

You have employee "Dental insurance" but the CCF hospital don't accept that insurance. Then why do you give that sort of insurance to your employee. 

Employee appreciation/motivation:  You will get 2 cookies/ year as a employee appreciation. 

Other than that, outside work, Cleveland is a NOISY city. People are loud, sirens even when not necessary. Roads are broken and dug everywhere, bog big potholes everywhere.  I broke my new cars wheel with a big cut on tire on my first day of moving to Cleveland. 

I can keep on going with many more.

review_title: Main Campus RNs--do your year and get out
pros:
24 hour Starbucks. 

Looks great on a resume. New grad RNs--get your year of experience then get out ASAP.

I enjoy the actual patient care. You do get a wide variety of critically ill patients that are "special cases" due to the size and ranking of the enterprise.

Insurance is incredible (although I have not had to use it).
cons:
Parking is a hot mess. Unless you've worked there for 5+ years good luck getting a spot at a parking garage less than a 15 minute walk away...did I mention its $70+/month? They aren't even safe half the time, nurses have been held at gunpoint and mugged before. Physicians get preferred spots, but half the time they aren't clearly marked and people get their cars booted. Some spots are clearly marked as "Physician Parking Only" and some say "Staff Parking."
 I'd like to think that as an RN that takes care of all those physician's patients that I'd be considered staff, right? Wrong. Got booted last week for parking in a "staff" spot...public safety told me it was supposed to say "physician parking only."

Floating...don't even get me started. Staffing will float you to every single freaking floor in the hospital. Sometimes for a full shift, sometimes for 8 hours, sometimes for 4, I've seen it for 2 before. Tell me how it's safe to have patients for 2 or 4 hours, you've barely gotten to know them, and now you're giving report to another nurse who will have them for who knows how long? I've had patients tell me they've gone through 3 nurses a shift before. That's absolutely ridiculous and not safe for patient care.

Most units require you to rotate weekends, especially if you are a new grad nurse or a new hire. There is no leniency on this. If you can't switch a shift with someone, you have to call off and get "points" (which you only get so many of and then go into corrective action). I've had to miss a friend's wedding, family vacations, and my nephew's first birthday party because I couldn't get a shift switched and am trying to save my call offs for when I am sick.

The J building (cardiac) gets state-of-the-art technology, beautiful rooms, etc because CC is known for being #1 in heart health. Meanwhile in other areas of the hospital we can't replace equipment because it's "not in the budget" or are running on ancient equipment.

There is virtually no shift diff for weekends and nights---this is HUGE considering most employees are rotating days/nights (which totally wrecks your sleeping schedule) and are required to work weekends.

job_title: Patient Service Representative in Stow, OH
pros: Great place to work for. Awesome benefits, great PTO. Pay is very generous. Almost every employee is kind. Current CCAG CEO is very nice and interacts with employees.
cons: Management is not always accommodating. Lack of communication.  All employees in my department are held to different standards of work ethic and can get away with things that others would get written up for. The office manager isn't present enough.

review_title: Great place to do research, but don't get lost in the bureaucracy!
pros: Cleveland Clinic truly is an excellent and cutting edge research institute. The level of care and the types of research being conducted are truly world-class.
cons: Mentorship really matters here, if you get a bad boss or mentor, leave, or change departments. also, the amount of bureaucracy and hoop jumping to get your research funded or IRB approved can be oppressive at times. Patience is essential.

pros: Cleveland Clinic is a good company to work for, good benefits and 401k.  The employees are very friendly an is a happy atmosphere for the most part.
cons: The management in my dept. was uneduacted about the job we did.  Not fair in scheduling.  The new people got the better schedules an the older ones were left with the worst shifts.  No credit for going above an beyond.  Not much chance for advancement.  The supervisor was totally unapprochable.

pros: Making a difference in patients' lives is at the heart of what all Cleveland Clinic employees do, which can be a very rewarding experience.
cons: The Clinic is very large, it's easy to overgeneralize. Its system is very hierarchical with the usual red-tape and politics. The HR department is often moving at glacier speed. Some career tracks in IT are underdeveloped or not competitive enough. Institutes, as well as their departments, have different cultures. As always, it depends on the people you end up working with whether it's going to be a positive experience.

review_title: Not a good place to work !!

review_title: Pretty much how everyone else feels.

review_title: This is a top notch organization and is a leader in the healthcare industry

pros: Learn a lot and have many experiences in health care outside of research. Make a lot of money in high school and maintain a work schedule.

review_title: The Worst Experience of My Professional Career
job_title: Research Program Manager in Cleveland, OH
pros: I met some great contacts and life-long friends.  Gave me a whole new perspective on priorities and helped me appreciate my current and past employers even more than I already had!
cons: I'm sure not every area is as bad as the one I was in, but this is by no means an exaggeration. There was very little respect given to employees.  Many departments are ruled by fear and intimidation.  I was given no tools or support to help my direct reports when they had issues.  I was even told by my supervisor that instead of trying to support or help my employees I should tell them if they don't like it maybe they should just leave.  It's very sad because there are some great people there with great skills, but it seems many in upper management have learned if they threaten they get what they want.  And still others are more than willing to try to make co-workers look bad so that they look better.  When the engagement surveys went out we were told if we didn't give high scores we would just create more work for ourselves so it's best to rate high no matter what.  I honestly still find it hard to believe it was that bad and I lived it.    Even after I gave my 2 week notice, I was told that I shouldn't tell people I was leaving.  I'm not sure why, I will try not to speculate.

pros: Health insurance and benefits, great tuition reimbursement for nursing students, nice severance package
cons: massive layoffs throughout the corporate enterprise but will take months to get hired once you apply...secretaries can have 3 interviews over a couple of months and STILL not get the job (once I made top 28, then top 7, then top 3 but not hired)

pros: Good benefits but not as good as the past. Support staff is good but they are all required to do more each year.
cons: It doesn't seem management knows what is going on especially at the regional sites. Support staff is pushed every year to do more or go somewhere else.

review_title: I don't even know where to begin
pros:
Tuition reimbursment
401k plan is with Fidelity
Ability to help others and make a difference in people's lives. 
After you are inevitably laid off, they offer an employment  coach to help you indefinitely until you find work. It really works.
cons:
Advice: 
Narcissism abounds. Treat managers and doctors like gods, and you  have a chance at survival. 
Don't bother with the wellness program. Heaven forbid if you fill one single prescription a few days late, you will be "out of compliance" and will fail to qualify for a lower health insurance rate. They dangle a carrot, and work hard to keep people from using it. 
Take full advantage of the tuition reimbursement!!! Once you hit the ceiling on salary for your position, you will be laid off. They will then "re-organize", change your job title, and hire someone else to do your same job at a much lower rate.  
If you have family or a significant other, instruct them to call the insurer immediately if you need an ambulance or to be seen at an out of network hospital.  Ignore the written agreement. The reality is that they will refuse  to pay and then stick you with the entire bill.  Yes, even if it is a true emergency. I'm not  making this up.  The moment it happens, get the doctor to document that it was a true medical emergency and that waiting or traveling  to a covered hospital was not medically advised.

pros: Wonderful staff that are extremely helpful and experienced. The commitment to patient care is evident in everyone attitudes.

review_title: Good place to start an initial research career

review_title: This is an exceptional institution that inculcates the values of caring giving in its providers.
